course.subject: SBMT
course.name: Social Enterprise Internship Program
course.description: The course is intended to give business undergraduate students an opportunity to gain exposure in the area of social entrepreneurship and apply their knowledge to solve real-world challenges facing these organizations.  It is conducted in the form of an internship program at a designated social enterprise under the supervision of the School of Business and Management.  Approval from the course coordinator is needed prior to enrolling in the course.  Graded P or F. Students may repeat the course for credits if different topics are taken.

reviews.author: Lawrence Tang
reviews.title: If you want to intern in NGO, this program is certainly NOT a good choice.
reviews.comment_content: I choose HKFYG Leadership Institute as my choice, and the supervisor, Iki Chan, is completely disastrous. She will take every chance to exploit any interns as their grade and reference letters are in her grasp. She will need you to OT everyday and sometimes even till Sunday 1-2am, but in the end won't use the work that you have done.
reviews.comment_teaching: The UST tutor himself is not helping nor understanding students' situation, and the rules and regulations of this course are completely biased to NGOs. Your pass/fail grade and start/end date are almost solely depends on your NGO supervisor, and the tutor would have an initial bias to NGO partners (e.g. he will say "I have cooperated with your supervisor for a long time and he/she is a good person.") before listening to any of your concerns. If you are fortunate enough to have a good supervisor then congratulations; however if not, you can do nothing except listening and obeying to your supervisor until the end of your internship, as he/she determines your grade.
reviews.comment_grading: This course only have pass and fail, and it is a 2 credit course, not 4. However, my supervisor will ask me questions like "Do you think I will fail you?" when I didn't do anything bad to the company or to herself. Generally supervisors in this course will not fail you if you didn't do anything destructive, but it is not guaranteed, only depends on who you met.
reviews.comment_workload: Extremely heavy. I would rather study one to two more subjects while in school instead of going to HKFYG to work. HKFYG always organize events which the manpower needed is very far exceed what they have. Thus, they will exploit interns and volunteers to help them get work done. No leaves (not even sick leave) are expected to take, and in my case, you won't be given any leave even though you have worked on weekends, while the supervisor will take leaves.

reviews.title: Don't pick HKFYP

reviews.author: Bismarck
reviews.title: Nice internship for Year 1 students
reviews.comment_content:
SBMT2200 is a one-month internship which requires students to work in a NGO. Tbh, it is a very nice experience and internship for year 1 students since most of the year 1 students wont get internship experience. It will be a great stepping stone for getting more internship experience.

The course is quite nice, dont be faked by other review XD since I think the course changed quite a lot (not sure haha).
reviews.comment_teaching: I think I have learnt since I am a newbie to workplace. I am quite sure that you can learnt a lot from the working experience (whatever good or bad).
reviews.comment_grading:
-Meet the expectations of the NGO, organization or business. That means, “showing up on time” and “doing the work expected in a quality manner”
-Submit a time sheet signed by your supervisor
- Submit a reflective paper (minimum 800 words) on activities
undertaken during the program
- Submit at least 8 digital photographs suitable for the SBM UG
Programs Office’s future promotion of the program (in jpeg format
1MB- 2MB, with at least one photo of you and your employer’s logo at the back)
- Submit a NGO evaluation form

They are some easy task that no one will mark it or not. And mostly the NGO will pass you (I've never heard ppl being failed)
reviews.comment_workload: Depends on the NGO you choose. For me, I chose a start-up which makes my workload a bit heavy, such as working on Saturday and Sunday for few hours. Although it seems a bit tough, but I recognise it as a valuable experience.

reviews.author: Mandy0709
reviews.title: Great internship opportunity for freshman
reviews.comment_content: This course is great for year1 students especially for the winter semester when you do not have much professional knowledge and working experience but want to make use of the winter semester. The interview is not that difficult and the main point is you have to show your passion in NGO or in the value of the NGO you choose to achieve. It will be better if you can show your relevant volunteer experience.
reviews.comment_teaching: The supervisor in my internship is nice and friendly. She was willing to give me many opportunities and instructions on my works. This was great to me as a year 1 freshman who just experienced one virtual semester. However, to be honest, for non-year1 students, the internship experience in SBMT 2200 might not be useful enough since my works were mainly about administration and sometimes marketing. This is not professional enough for non-year1 students no matter in skillset learning or on the CV.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade is only P or F. The grading policy is only on the attendance in the internship period, submission of the eight photos (the photos are not limited to any content but relevant to the internship) and the essay, and attendance in the last reflection session (only lasting for 15 minutes).
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light. For those NGOs having a well-established structure. the works are usually planned by the supervisor. For those NGOs having a shorter history, the works are usually more sudden but limited. In my internship experience, usually there was one task for a day. Therefore, the light workload does not mean a good thing in this case. Since by a month, the knowledge  I learned did not deserve such a long time.
